title: Is it okay to use the AP style in fiction? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are lots of different acceptable styles for fiction. I like the AP style a lot because it’s informal. In dialogue it’s more like the characters would really talk in real life. If you go strictly by Strunk and White by contrast, the dialogues will often sound stilted and awkward, not at all like anyone ever really talks these days. My last two novels and my current WIP are set in the Dark Ages. Many authors writing about that time would use a very formal style and mix in a few Old English words, trying to make the dialogue sound authentic. It’s false authenticity though. British people of that time didn’t speak Old English and they certainly didn’t speak formally as you hear in the corny dialogue in movies about the Arthurian Age. The British people in those days spoke a crude dialect which was a mixture of ancient Celtic languages and Latin (the latter being a holdover from Roman occupation). I write fantasy novels about Elves and some authors and movie actors seem to think Elves speak very formal English like the upper class in England does — how silly. Since my readers don’t speak any of those tongues in everyday speech, I feel free to use modern informal dialogue because I think that will help readers relate to my characters better. I don’t know what sort of fiction you’re writing but I can’t think of any genre where an excessively formal style would help your readers relate better but I think the AP style certainly would. No publisher will mind. As for readers, if you’re writing any sort of period piece you will always get critics saying, “People didn’t talk that way back then.” They won’t be jarred though, they’re just finding something to fuss about. The only thing, style-wise, you should worry about is whether AP style helps your readers relate to the plot and the characters better than a more formal style. As for figuring out what will jar readers and what will please them, find a good editor and let them have a crack at your rough draft. Personally, I’ve learned a lot about style from my editor. Both of us feel free to break the rules of style manuals when it suits the story. The main rule of writing is, all the rules of writing are made to be broken and best-selling authors do it all the time.

Not sure about American Publishers but we have similar style guides in Germany and I have yet to meet an editor or publisher of fiction who seriously gives a damn (except maybe when you use footnotes and citations in your novel: These should at least be consistent). As long as your text is an enjoyable read, reasonably error-free and consistent in its style, I don’t think it matters all that much. As I said, I don’t know about American Publishers. Maybe you can do a little survey among agents and publishers and take a look at those publishers that fit your novel best.

If that’s the style you’re comfortable with…why not? In my experience, different publishers lean toward different guidelines for their editing. Many go with The Chicago Manual of Style, but not all. Moreover, many have their own “house” style—and there’s no way that an author will know exactly what that is. I’ve never seen a book turned down because it used a different professional style. Write a great book, then hope you get a great editor wherever the book lands. Good luck!

I’ve never worked for a book publisher or any type of fiction publisher, so I’m probably not the best person to answer this. That said, I would presume most publishing houses would take a manuscript written in AP style and edit it to match that publishing company’s style manual. They probably wouldn’t find it jarring. They probably wouldn’t recognize that you’re writing in AP style, though they might notice that you don’t italicize anything. Thanks for asking me to answer.

When writing, you can use any style you want. Different publishers and editors use different style guides when copy-editing, but the technicalities of these guides apply more to non-fiction than fiction. As with Helmut’s comment, consistency and freedom from error is more important than strict adherence to any particular guide.
Yes, and some publishers, including BOLD VENTURE PRESS, find it preferable. boldventurepress.com
I go with the Strunk & White style. :-) Big publishers will have a house editor. Small publishers will have an ‘out-house’ editor. If this is your biggest problem, you are in good shape.
It’s fiction, write whatever you want. But, keep in mind “okay” is never OK.
